items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Highest tide level is expected to be at Kilnsea Village between 5:00 AM until 7:00 AM on 08/10/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated following the tide tomorrow morning, 08/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels will rise again today as a response to further rainfall.  The forecast is for rain this morning, heavy at times, which will lessen in intensity and frequency as the morning progresses. Rivers and Lakes levels will rise for a time as a result of the rain before peaking this afternoon. Derwent Water will remain high affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water.  Areas most at risk are the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We continue to monitor levels closely and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 08/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  

The risk of flooding from the River South Tyne has now reduced. We expect river levels to continue to fall throughout this afternoon (Friday, 07/10/2022). 

No further flooding to low lying roads, riverside footpaths and farmland is expected, however there may be standing water. 

We will continue to monitor river levels closely.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.description: Rivers Greta, St Johns Beck and Bassenthwaite Lake

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Greta, St Johns Beck, Glendermackin

items.message: River and lake levels remain high following a response to further rainfall today. River and lake levels are expected to peak this afternoon and will start receding later today and into the weekend. Derwent Water will remain high affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. We continue to monitor levels closely and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated later tomorrow 08/10/2022 or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising steadily on the Walverden Water due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include Walverden Water comprising of properties off and including Bradley Road, Sagar Street, Brook Street, Southfield Street, Pendle Industrial Estate and Riverside Business Park.
Flooding is possible at Walverden Water comprising of properties off and including Bradley Road, Sagar Street, Brook Street, Southfield Street, Pendle Industrial Estate and Riverside Business Park from 01:30 PM on 07/10/2022.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon.
River levels are forecast to rise.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 08:30 PM on 07/10/2022, or as the situation changes.
